awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Geothermal Battery Energy Storage Technical Feasibility
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project addresses the geotechnical engineering research needed to assess the feasibility of using the earth (a geothermal sedimentary reservoir) as a "battery" for large-scale energy storage to help manage the intermittent nature of solar and wind electricity generation. A geothermal battery would store solar generated hot water in the earth, and withdraw it as steam or use it in a hot water binary-cycle electricity generation system when needed, particularly when solar and wind are not available. Solar and wind electricity are being introduced into electric grids to supplement conventional electricity production, driven substantially by a desire to "decarbonize" electricity production, and more recently due to falling prices of solar and wind energy. Such introduction has in some ways been "too successful" leading to short-term curtailments of some solar and wind production. Also, electricity can be provided by solar and wind only when the sun shines and the wind blows, resulting in fluctuating production of electricity. Meanwhile, the deployment of "utility scale storage" (sometimes referred to as "grid scale") has not kept pace with this intermittent nature of solar, and to a lesser extent wind. The battery concept would utilize an existing geo-heated reservoir, but one where the reservoir temperature is too low to be economically viable. The addition of heat produced by solar thermal may be able to raise the low-grade geothermal reservoir temperature enough to utilize it efficiently for steam/binary cycle electricity production. To a large extent, this storage concept is all "renewable energy" drawing on geothermal energy and solar thermal energy combined. If feasible, the implementation of this storage concept would improve the reliability and extent of solar and wind electricity throughout areas of the nation, resulting in less reliance on carbon-based fuels. 

Energy storage that is cost competitive is essential in order to continue the addition of solar and wind electricity without great disruptions. This project focusses on the determination if a Geothermal Battery Energy Storage System is technically feasible at a potentially competitive cost. A steering committee will meet at the start of the project to provide planning guidance, and near the conclusion of the project to provide tentative consensus conclusions. A concluding workshop will be held where findings will be reviewed and consensus conclusions presented. The results of the project will add to the existing knowledge base by exploring technical phenomena related to the Geothermal Battery Energy Storage concept, including thermal energy movement within a geo-reservoir; rock expansion that occurs when heating the reservoir; the chemical effect on the rock due to the cyclic heating and cooling of the reservoir; and the potential for induced seismicity as thermal expansion and the injection of water into the reservoir produce certain fault movements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced understanding of reservoir thermal energy storage. Those concepts are not new and offer attractive direct heating applications. However, today, possibly even greater value can be attributed to large-scale, long-term thermal energy storage for later conversion to electricity. This importance arises from the substantial contributions of solar- and wind-generated electricity to the domestic electric grid. The intermittent nature of solar and wind requires such storage. No cost-effective technique, beyond pumped hydro, has been proven. Chemical batteries certainly play a role, but for large-scale and long-term storage they are currently cost-prohibitive. There is an alternative - Geothermal Battery Energy Storage. This form of reservoir thermal energy storage exploits high porosity and high permeability sedimentary formations. Native, commercial geothermal conditions are not a pre-requisite. Such formations have previously received only limited consideration for subsurface heat storage. 

 

One manifestation of the geothermal battery concept uses solar heat collectors to heat water on the surface. The heated water is then injected deep into the earth for storage, thereby combining solar and geothermal energy. That is, the hot water injected effectively creates a productive geothermal reservoir at any location where adequate solar radiance and proper geology exist. Using this created geothermal reservoir, conventional geothermal electricity is produced as dispatchable electricity. Furthermore, by using the naturally occurring connate water, fresh water is not required to create the geothermal reservoir. For a geothermal battery to provide large-scale and long-term heat storage for later use, the reservoir must be considered. That was the focus of this project. Engineering for surface facilities is fundamentally developed; it is the subsurface storage that is least constrained from an engineering perspective.

 Project Outcomes

This project made extensive numerical calculations that define critical reservoir parameters governing heat and fluid flow and identified at least some of the geochemical ramifications. The high porosity rock can be considered as the storage tank, and water is the working medium to carry heat from the surface to the storage tank, and then back to the surface when heat is needed. Of particular note, the high porosity formation allows a relatively small rock matrix volume to store large amounts of hot water. In turn, this small volume allows for selecting subsurface storage sites that are away from complex layering, fractures, and faulting. Adjacent sealing is a prerequisite, as in any subsurface storage scenario.

The project identified reservoir and injection/production parameters that would allow nearly all of the injected heat to be practically recovered. This is particularly true if the thermal reservoir is intelligently commissioned with a modest charging period. During this charging period, heated fluid is injected without recovery before diurnal or seasonal cycling (injection/shut-in/production) begins. This energy efficiency is somewhat offset by parasitic pumping costs. These operational costs could be offset to some extent by using solar photovoltaic (or excess generated electricity) to drive pumps. Efficient heat recovery is critical for any reservoir thermal energy storage system to be economically viable.

In addition to extensive calculations, the project conducted an online workshop/webinar with experts addressing the following topics.

  • Heat and fluid flow calculations,
  • Operational considerations and well layouts,
  • Challenges of sedimentary basins,
  • Site potential from an oil & gas industry perspective,
  • Geochemical considerations, and,
  • Surface facilities.

This workshop brought together experts to address specific aspects of the geothermal battery for storage and electric generation. Overall, these expert presentations tended to stimulate significant discussion among the nearly 250 participants. The presentations and interaction with a multi-disciplinary audience highlighted subsurface heat storage and emphasized the potential to store heat to provide gigawatt-hours of electricity for daily, monthly, or even seasonal utilization scenarios. Although engineering issues must be addressed for any given geothermal battery emplacement, no insurmountable problems were noted. Field demonstration is a next step to validate calculations and modeling for given geothermal battery layouts. Beyond the workshop, several related publications are in various stages of peer review and presentation. These include:

  1. Panja, P., Green, S., and McLennan, J. 2020. Temperature and Pressure Profiles for Geothermal Battery Energy Storage in Sedimentary Basins, ARMA 20-1411, prepared for the 54th US Rock Mechanics/Geomechanics Symposium (ARMA 2020), in press.
  2. Green, S., McLennan, J., Panja, P., Kitz, K., Allis, R., and Moore, J. 2020. Geothermal Battery Energy Storage, Renewable Energy, in press.
  3. Green, S., McLennan, J., Panja, P., Kitz, K., Allis, R., and Moore, J. 2020. Questions and Considerations Regarding the Geothermal Battery Energy Storage Reservoir, submitted to Nature Energy.

It is clear that the earth is an extremely good thermal insulator and stored, relatively high-temperature water will experience minimal heat loss out of the reservoir even over long residence times. Large amounts of thermal energy can be stored in relatively small reservoir volumes, with high recovery efficiencies.
